content:
18
												It's a great little game, emphasis on little.In no particular order, here are a few things to note:Visuals:The illustrations leave a lot to be desired, but the sprites are lively and cute.Like many small games, Recettear uses 2D sprites on ugly 3D backgrounds when you're in combat (which is a LOT).There are only four customers. Sometimes, a lot of the same one will show up... and it's kinda creepy.Enemy designs are also limited. Most are just palette swaps of the first dungeon's enemies.The HUD is clean & easy to navigate. It could use some polish, but it's fine as it is.It offers windowed & fullscreen.Music:The shop's theme is pleasantly happy.You'll get tired of the looping dungeon music... but it's nothing that bad.The game has full volume control. You can mute effects and music independently.Story:By far, the worst part of the game. Characters are flat, one-dimensional and generally boring. So, don't be expecting some Harvest Moon-style relationships to develop.Each companion has a miniature story that's revealed through events.This is not a RPG, its story is extremely short and it resets to the beginning once you pay off your loan.Due to the reset, you'll often see a character's first event several times before you see their second, simply because you weren't focusing on their story in your previous playthroughs. Events ARE skippable, though, so don't panic.The dialogue often strains to be funny, but just sounds dumb. There are a lot of flat jokes, clumsy references, etc.GameplayRecettear uses a mix of time management and dungeon crawling that's like a very stripped down version of Persona 3.This not a shop simulator. It's a dungeon crawler with a shop mini-game. You will need to spend a LOT of time in the dungeons.Combat is really simple. Companions have only one normal attack and a few, often useless, special attacks that consume mana. It's boring and mindless, but sometimes that's what you want in a game.The shop mini-game is fun and relaxing. You can change the shop's look, put items on display and haggle over the prices.Unfortunately, haggling is pointless (and the game penalizes you for doing it). Since all generic customers have one of four fixed budget ranges, you'll quickly find the "sweet spot" for prices and stick with it.Spoiler-free Tips:Remember to visit the blacksmith. He'll eventually offer item crafting and shop expansions.Items that you're buying will still show the "Price Up" and "Price Down" colors (red & blue). Don't be fooled, you're the only merchant these matter to. The blacksmith & wholesaler will still charge the normal price. This means you can buy a bunch of hot items and turn them for massive profits. (Assuming you don't overbuy!)The "mood" of the store's decorations affects which companions show up to shop.Customers start with small budgets. It is absolutely essential that you increase them by buying/selling items WITHOUT haggling and at prices within their "sweet spot". If you don't do this, they won't be able to afford the more expensive items... and you'll be screwed.Don't neglect your Merchant Level. Raising it is how you unlock crafting recipes and store expansions. Your Merchant Level increases the same way customers' budgets do... so that's one more reason to NOT haggle and make sure you hit that sweet spot.In case it wasn't obvious, the "Near" and "Just" bonuses that you see after transactions are indications that your price was in the sweet spot. (i.e. near it, on it)All told, it's a simple game that offers simple joys. People who like grinding for crafting ingredients will enjoy Recettear, since that's by far the largest part of it. The rest of us can also find some fun redecorating the shop and playing the mini-game. Get it on sale, if you're interested.Oh, and I strongly recommend newcomers google a guide on making money. The game is short and the loan payments ramp up VERY fast. For those who don't want to "cheat", let me just say reselling sweets (Watermelon, Takiyaki) is a good starting point and Mermaid Shoes (Level 1 Shoes) are very profitable once you unlock item crafting. They're made of Leather Boots (from the Wholesaler) + Water Crystal (dropped by black knights).

												Capitalism, Ho!You play as a kawaii as ♥♥♥♥ little girl, who suddenly has a mountain of debt thrown at her because her father left her to go an adventure. Do you despair at this notion? Nope, you become an aspiring capitalist that wrings cash out from characters straight out of your typical JRPG.Buy low, Sell high and amass money to pay off your father's debt and crush your competition. Managing your wares to maximize profit and customer satisification are the best part of the game. You will find yourself going dungeon exploring with hired mercenaries, that you can pimp out with gear, to get better ♥♥♥♥ to sell. Balance, the admitely kind of shallow dungeon sections with smalls ammounts enemy variety, looting and running your shop in one of several modes. content:
y 23
												Recettear is a very cute game about a girl and a fairy owning a dodgy item shop that scams the hell out of your customers while putting on an innoncent smile. The main gameplay inside the store involves a lot of haggling and knowing just how much money you can squeeze out of your customer's wallets before they cry and leave your store. Outside of the store, you get to pay other suckers to go into a dungeon with you to kill monsters that are also trying to kill them while you collect all their hard-earned loot, which you can then sell at your shop for more money. The battle mechanic is also unnecessarily amazingly interactive for a game whose focus is on ripping people off owning a store. Coupled with a lot of cool character interactions, cute and catchy musics and a lot of end-game exploration/content, the game really offers a lot of addiction replayability.Overall, a very realistic game about owning a business. 10/10 capitalism, ho!

content:
, 2011
												The appeal of Recettear is not immediately obvious. Gameplay which is a lite mesh of dungeon crawl and economic sim, limited and cutesy graphics, irritating sound with untranslated voiceovers… However, it is definitely a case of the sum being greater than the parts. It is certainly a game which you can jump straight into – well, once you figure out how to get past the menu. For keyboard users, the select button is not obvious (for the record, it's 'z', which was only discovered after a minute of keyboard mashing…). There is regular and in-context help through the game which establishes the basics. Success, however, requires a lot of experimentation and awareness of what works. Some parts of the game feel a bit like a cross between Majesty and Diablo. While you control them directly in the dungeon, they buy equipment and make themselves available at their own initiative. It's quite possible to go through the main storyline with several adventurers never becoming available. Also, while you can loan them items, this takes valuable loot space. It's much better to sell to them, but since that's something you can't control, it takes a lot of manipulation (or luck) to get them properly equipped. The game's key storyline – paying off a debt weekly through profits from the item shop – lends purpose to the gameplay without completely restricting it. Indeed, the tight time limits provide much of the game's fun and challenge. Choosing to go for a last-ditch dungeon run to pick up high-priced items and risking not having enough time to sell them and make up the debt is just one example of the agonising strategic decisions to be made. Indeed, weighing up choices is a big part of the game. Stick with an expensive and high-levelled adventurer who can work the tougher dungeons or sacrifice the bigger rewards to build up another who may prove to be more powerful in the long run? Sell a useful item to an adventurer at a discount, or get every possible bit of money from a non-adventurer? Attract a certain type of customer with a dark store, or keep things light and draw another? Sacrifice several items to forge one? For what looks like a very slimmed-down mesh of two types of game, it presents a lot of challenges. Though failure is very possible, especially on a first run, it's possible to carry on with some of the assets you have collected. This makes the next attempt easier, eliminating a potential frustration. The writing is generally good, with some entertaining, and occasionally quite heart-warming, dialogue. The setting is interesting enough, though there is not that much to learn about it. Bring on a sequel! Sound is probably the least impressive aspect, and it gets downright annoying in dungeons. Switch it off and put on your own music.Just look at the hours played - that's the best endorsement I can give it.

content:
, 2011
												Next time you’re off galavanting around a massive RPG world, slaying monsters and fulfilling your destiny, spare a thought for the shopkeeper in the last town who sold you all your gear. Without them, you’d be a nobody – you’d have no sword, no armor, no healing products. Confined to a live of standing behind that counter, all for your benefit. Except that, thanks to satirical shopkeep-em-up Recettear: An Item Shop’s Tale, we now know the truth – RPG shopkeepers lead an even more exciting life than their customer heroes. It can be a little too difficult to begin with, but stick at it and you’ll find one of the best RPGs of the year.With its delightful mixture of store simulation and dungeon crawling adventure RPG elements, Recettear is a refreshing twist on the usual adventure style RPG. It’s funny without being annoying, addictive without being too repetitive and has deceptively deep gameplay.Overall, Recettear is a charming game well worth the money!

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Remember how the most fun to be had in Skyrim was trying to get the maximum most valuable loot from every dungeon, cackling with glee as you then sell it off to about five different shops, amassing huge amounts of cash, so much that money becomes meaningless to you, the glorious and unstoppable trillionaire Dragonborn?Yeah, me too.If, however, methodical and obsessive treasure selling and cash hoarding is actually not among your favorite RPG memories, your mileage with this game may very. Forget robotic NPCs, dragon hunting, falling off mountains. This game cuts out all the extraneous crud, leaving you with only the very best: treasure hoarding, buying and selling. All the cackling with glee, none of the frustration. Nothing to stand between you and the rapidly increasing numbers, the juggling and sorting of a thousand little items, the excitment and joys of haggling and customer service. It's the game you never knew you needed but always secretly wanted in your heart of hearts. You might stare at the screen in disbelief, thinking no game about just buying and selling items has any right to be so dang fun. But I never stop loving the ring of that cash register, or high-fiving the nearest living human or cat or whatever's nearby when I amass 500,000+ moneys in one day because sweets were on sale, and just sitting and smiling as I enter dungeons with my wizard friend, exploding enemies in bursts of beautiful fire so we can gather more items. It's addictive and fun and basically the best thing ever. Of course, because this game truly knows the joys of the methodical and obssessive item seller, it knows you'll get burnt out if all you do is sit behind a counter and watch numbers roll, no matter how satsifying and enjoyable that may be for a while. So it's the delightful writing and characters, the brief but highly enjoyable story events, that truly make this one of the best games I've ever played. You've got a lovely cast of truly charming characters keeping things interesting, and stories of just the right size, scale, and length, that add to the game without detracting from it. You've got simple but fairly fun dungeon diving that manages to not be too tedious. And the game is drowning in humor, and some inexplicable, surprising things that can be delightful to stumble across (fish? FISH?!). The game is laughing. You're laughing. We're all laughing. It's even got a corny theme song. How can you not love it, I ask you!? Only some fiend who hates items would hate this game. Begone, fiend! Stick to your mountains and troll slaying, why don't you! Ride away on your dragon! We'll be rolling around on our mountains of cash, partying with our customers, buying awesome new decor and counters and books about DOOOOMSDAAAAY. You won't be missed.  One thing I was worried about was replay value, and just how long this thing could actually go on and still be fun. My fears, however, were soothed! There is a surprisingly large amount of story content, enough to last you for months (mabye even years, I don't know, I'm not there yet) if you don't binge-play the game too intensely. There's more than one game mode and lots of items to collect and dungeon diving to do and you can just keep trying to get better and better at haggling and learning all the characters and basically there's all sorts of goals you can strive for and stuff that'll keep you busy and invested. So that's good! I was dreading that it would all come to a halt or wind up boring but nope, it just stays awesome forever. Dream come true.I also like that it's casual enough that I don't have to invest huge amounts of brainpower to it, but deep enough that I can dive in and have fun and it's still a satisfying experience. If you're a busy person you can devote a few hours to it (or even thirty minutes, fifteen minutes, you can save whenver you want) and it probably won't suck your life away. YAYTL;DR: play this game if you like items and/or selling stuff and/or numbers/moneys

content:
4, 2015
												A fun game with a good amount of content, but gets repetitive after a while.In Recettear, you're a shopkeeper trying to pay off your father's debts. Every week, you need to pay a set amount of your loan, and you need to pay more and more every week.To earn money to pay said debt off, you sell items to customers. Items are acquired by either adventuring into dungeons, or buying them from the market.You've got a shop with a certain amount of counters where you can sell items. You'll be bargaining with your customers for the best price, as each customer has budgets you'll learn.You can decorate and expand your shop, and the way you decorate influences who comes to your shop. You can also influence who comes into your shop using the window display, which is the counter in front of the window.There's also a merchant level, which is raised by selling and buying items from your customers. As it is raised, you can do more things to your shop, such as expanding it, unlocking vending machines, getting new items for sale in the market, etc.The prices for things also fluctuate. There might be a shortage of food, for example, so you can sell your stock of food for twice their base price. If there is low demand for weapons, you'll have to sell your weapons for a much lower price.This actually makes things very interesting, as you can buy items from the market while their price is low, to make an even bigger profit.Adventuring is when you pay an adventurer to go into a dungeon to kill monsters and get items. There's eight adventurers, each having different abilities and attacks. In dungeons, you're going to be finding chests and monsters, along with occasional bosses.These adventurers are unlocked over time, some by fighting them as a dungeon boss, others with more specific requirements, such as talking to them in the Town Square, or selling items to them enough times.When you kill monsters in dungeons, sometimes they'll drop crafting materials, which you can use to craft items you can sell for a large profit.There's a few big problems with Recettear. Most importantly, the way markets are handled.In dungeons, there is a small chance you'll actually get something worthwhile, something you'll make a profit with that is worth the large amount of in-game time you'll take to get it.Dungeons take a large amount of the day to enter, which could be better spent having your shop open to sell items.You'll make much more of a profit if you buy items in the market and sell them yourself for a higher price. Doing this, you'll have plenty of time in the day to sell what you've bought for more of a profit for what you'd get from your dungeon findings.The problem lies with large the profit from the market and the guild is. A big part of this is how cheap items that are currently raised in price are.Say an item has a base price of 8,000. If this item is in high demand, you can sell it for 200% of its base price, or 16,000, plus whatever else you'll add to the price according to your customer's budget for a profit.The market sells this item for 5,500-6,500. Right there is a pretty big profit of roughly 2,000, but in high demand, this item is sold for around 8,000-10,500.At the least, that is around a 5,000 currency profit, without raising the doubled base price for a profit.That really makes the whole "fluctuating price" thing not really worthwhile, if you don't have to worry about loosing money when buying an item in high demand, and yet you can still make such a big profit off of it afterwards. There's no reason to buy things from the market during low demand, since there isn't enough of a profit to warrant waiting until items are low in demand to stock up.Trying to beat the game through dungeons isn't really possible. As some point, you're going to be relying on the market for profits.The game also gets very repetitive because of this. While going into dungeons would spruce up the gameplay, your days are going to be spent either going through the market menu or having your shop open. Selling is enjoyable, but it gets tiring when it is one of the only two things you're going to be doing.Dungeons, while adding variety, are kind of tiring and boring after a while. While the different adventurers can make things interesting, it is just a simple top-down dungeon with enemies. There aren't really enough dungeons in this game either, totaling at 5, with one in endless mode, but they do last until the endgame, with the last one unlocking at merchant level 100.You're going to be spending a lot of time fighting the same enemies and collecting the same items, during the time between just unlocking a new dungeon and trying to get a new one.There's a decent amount of content in this game, from crafting all the items to getting all of the adventurers. There's also your merchant level, which, in New Game +, carries over, so you can get to higher levels and unlock items then you couldn't a single playthrough. There are five weeks of payment in this game, with the last week's payment being 500,000.There's also an Endless Mode which is unlocked by getting to the end of the game, in which the game doesn't end and the debt keeps getting bigger and bigger until you can't pay it.Despite all the negativity, this really is a fun game. Running the shop is enjoyable, crafting new items is fun, and trying to unlock all of the adventurers is very entertaining.One of my big positives is the varying budgets everyone has that you'll learn as you play. As your customer reputation increases, which is accomplished by giving them a good deal, or selling an item on your first price, their budget will increase, so they can buy more expensive items. You'll get Merchant Level EXP bonuses for knowing the budgets and price ranges of your customers, so learning each of them is useful. Your reputation is also lowered for haggling too much or scaring away a customer with a high price, so you need to be careful with how much you're asking for.Another thing I like is how many items you can craft. There really is a lot of items, and you'll often craft weapons and armor for your adventurers stronger than anything you could buy from the guild for them.Overall, I definitely think this game warrants a look, as it is a fun game with a decent amount of content, but just gets repetitive after long periods of play. Lots of items, interesting customer budget/reputation system that is very interactive, lots of unlockables, and is actually pretty difficult.Markets are too strong and kind of dwarf dungeons, and you'll be repeating the same daily schedule for a while, but otherwise, this game is enjoyable and interesting.

												The only word I can really think of when I try to explain Recettear or rather how much I've managed to get into this game is "silly". The fact that it looks like some Peggle level casual game glazed in Moe and sprinkled with babies first market simulator should be more than enough to keep someone away from it were they to just skim the surface of it but believe it or not this is surprisingly immersing.  There are more than enough items in the game to make you have to put in effort to get a hold of all of them and in some cases causing you to work for hours to get  a single item (That's right folks, the dreaded RPG grind is present). Every sale will net you "Merchant experience" which will help you make it further into the 50 levels required to unlock all 29 level bonus which are expansions to your store, dungeon backpack and range of items available for you to buy or craft along with new abilities such as buying items from customers and taking orders in advance.But buy and selling items alone wouldn't make the game all that much fun would it? There are also Six dungeons for you to adventurer into with one of the eight adventurers you've managed to acquire. The floors in the dungeons range from 5 to 100 and the monster vary from dungeon to dungeon and floor to floor making each of them feel different from the last. The dialog is quirky and cute and the gameplay is usually simple but fun. This game has my yayifications and I would recommend at least trying the demo to anyone. CAPITALISM HO!

content:
er 31, 2015
												This game does nothing better than completely make you one with the world. At times you'll feel filthy rich, and other times, completely helpless. As you run the shop every day, the game teaches you very early on that you must be as efficient as possible to maximize profit and not lose the game (and your home). Even though collection day seems like a far-off hurdle, you must not remain complacent with your business. All it takes is a haggle taken too far, or purchases made too carelessly to ruin you. As Tear counts your 80,000pix fee only to count 79,860pix.... Well, game over. Your payment is void.Much like running a business, this game is difficult. You have get it right once. When you lose you have to start over from day one. Fortunately, you and your adventurers retain all levels, experience, and materials you've acquired, except starting with 1000pix again. Unfortunately, you have to run through all the dungeons from the beginning.There's a lot to stomach when you first run through the game. Eventually you have to keep track of orders and making sure you have a wide variety of stock. I have notes scribbled on my desk about how one customer never purchases anything at 115%, and how this customer buys at around 125~130% of cost. It can also feel grindy at times when you're in the dungeons fighting enemies. But what makes Recettear so warm and inviting is the fact that you are so much a part of this world as much as the next NPC. No matter how hard it is to make ends meet in your store, you are still a participant in the town around you. Your business, customers, and explorations are as real and as stressful as you want them to be. To paraphrase Tear, "It's more of an art than a science. There's no map to follow." There are so many variables to take into account. Recettear is not so much a simulation, than it is an experience.

content:
y 16, 2016
												In most RPG settings you clear out dungeons, then go and sell the unwanted items to shopkeepers.In Recettear, however, you are the shopkeeper. Forced into opening a shop by a loan shark fairy to pay off your father's huge adventuring debts, you need to pay off increasingly huge installments each week or lose your home as collateral.The game starts of simple enough, but as you progress the game will introduce new features, such as customers placing orders for you to fulfil later, and market fluctuations that will allow you to both buy low and sell high, increasing your profits significantly given the right situation. You can even sponsor adventurers to explore dungeons for you, and during these sessions you'll control them as they fight monsters and explore ruins. The main reasons for doing this is to give you ingredients to combine to make better equipment for the shop, and to unlock more adventurers to play as. Some of them will even come to your store and buy better equipment and weapons for themselves, increasing their effectiveness in the optional combat sections of the game. You'll probably even end up giving huge discounts to the adventurers you hire the most just so they'll be powerful and keep coming back for more deals. It's this kind of thing that really adds to the game's charm and helps you care about the side characters as you learn more about them.The game is actually very forgiving and failure to meet a payment will send you back to the second day with your inventory, adventurer levels and store reputation intact. This makes something that could have been a very frustrating experience stay fun and oddly relaxing, although it is possible to beat the game in a single run if you feel up for the challenge. Completing the game unlocks the ability to start a new game +, survival mode where you need to pay off increasing amounts of debt each week until it becomes impossible to pay back, or simply carry on where you left off without needing to worry about a deadline each week. Combined with the large amount of items you can discover and create this results in a good replay value, especially for completionists.As for downsides, the game is bad at explaining itself from the first tutorial. Tear will start the game off by telling you to set the prices for around 130%, but this will actually anger most of the customers and will cause less people to come to your store from the very beginning. You're actually better off selling for 106% - 112% until the public start liking you more, causing the shoppers to eventually warm up to buying the later and more expensive objects you can unlock, and raising your combo to speed up leveling. Neither the level combo nor town reputation are mentioned in the tutorials, which is strange considering they're actually very important to succeeding at the game and it can be frustrating until you realize they are both major factors in your progress.The dungeon exploration is also very repetitive after a while, but is necessary in order to unlock more of the side stories and characters to come to your store. Since merchant levels are more important to success than your adventurers' combat levels you'll probably ignore the dungeons after a certain amount of time to play the markets, especially after you unlock items in the market that make the payouts from these sessions seem small in comparison.If you're looking for an original take on the traditional JRPG setting and like the idea of running a store in a fantasy realm then I'd strongly recommend picking Recettear up.

content:
31, 2016
												The cool thing about Recettear is that it's setting is that of a typical fantasy RPG town, but the gameplay is nothing like that. You're already familiar with the setting and the tropes, but it's a new experience since you come at it from a different angle.You are a young girl who is severely in debt to a bank run by fairies (millenial problems.) To pay off the debt you convert your family home into an item shop for all those fantasy RPG adventurers that wander through your town. The core of the gameplay is just buying merchandise and then selling it to your customers. There are however some other variations on that, people in the town can help you out, you can market your stuff in various ways, and you can venture out into the wilderness to gather merchandise directly from the source (dungeons and monsters) rather than buying it all wholesale.So the core gameplay is pretty simple, but unless you're already an economist you'll likely find it pretty intimidating at first. I know I did. I made all the payments for my debt but each time I only just barely was able to meet each installment. Every time it got close to my due date I stressed out and pressed all my customers even harder in order to get by. It was actually fairly stressful.So if you're interested in becoming an episode of Pawn Stars: JRPG Town this is a great game. But don't say I didn't warn you if you end up blowing a blood vessel.

content:
y 31, 2014
												This is my first Steam review, and I've chosen to do it about this wonderful little gem: Recettear. I have to admit that when I bought this game, I did it purely on a whim one day when it was on sale, and I really was not expecting much. But this game really ended up surprising me, and in a very good way.You are Recette, a young girl who ends up being forced to repay her fathers debts and are accompanied by Tear, the fairy who was sent to recover the debts payment. Together the two of you open up a store, Recettear, so that you can make enough money to repay what you owe. The gameplay can be roughly divided into two parts: store management and dungeon crawling.Each day in the game is divided into 4 time slots and you can choose what to do for each one: go to town to hit the market to stock up on goods, visit the guild to grab an adventurer for some dungeon crawling or tend to your store. Store management is the main aspect of the game and in my own opinion the most fun. It also has a surprising depth to it. Make sure to buy stock when price is low and sell items when their value is higher. Choose what to put up for sale. Barter with you customers and fulfill their special orders. Change the look of your store to suit it to certain customers preferences.There are several adventurers you will meet and that you can take with you to do some dungeon crawling. There are several dungeons with multiple levels and bosses in the game, and exploring them will get you several items you can sell at your store or use in recipes to create better items. Exploring the dungeons also serves to advance the story which, without spoiling anything major, actually continues far beyond when you have finally managed to pay your fathers debts.The game has a really interesting story and likable characters. Cute is really the best way to describe the way the game looks. A special mention must be given to the games english translation which is really well done. Once your debt is paid for the first time, some new game modes are unlocked, and the game has a considerable replayability value if your goal is to get all items in the game (doing so will require starting a new game once for each adventurers loyalty item). It should be noted that it is possible to start a new game and carry over all the money, items and store upgrades from your other saves. This is helpful when only trying to get each adventurers loyalty item since you do not have to worry about making enough money to pay off the debt in the early phase of the game.There are two things I feel I should mention though: in my experience, dungeon crawling can be very tiresome and repetitive which is why I feel this is the least interesting aspect of the game. This is especially problematic if you want to get all items, which requires doing A LOT of grinding. The shop management aspect can become something you can do almost mechanically once you've upgraded the shop to the max, unlocked all possible items in the market and have gotten used to each customers characteristics when bartering. In my opinion this doesn't take any of the fun away from this aspect though.Finally, to end this review. If you do not like anything with a cute/anime aesthetic, or if you are looking for an action packed game do not buy this. To everyone else looking for a nice little way of occupying your time, I can only fully recommend it.

content:
y 1, 2014
												This cute little bartering game, with optional extras, is a cute time passer. So your dad is out to save the world, cool right? WRONG! Maybe it would be cool, ya know, if his broke ♥♥♥ didn't get himself killed by a dragon trying to pay off a loan shark. Anyways, this leaves you alone with the choice of having everything you know and own reposessed, or working for a slave-driving fairy in an item shop she puts together in your house so you're not forced to live in a card board box. No really, if you don't pay back her increasing payment deadlines, you will end up in a cardboard box, enjoy the building pressure.Recettear in a nut shell is like I said before a bartering RPG. You constantly sell items hopeing to have enough to pay back your next deadline. The value of items constantly changes as time goes by and the story is fun with a 'special' kind of humor. I enjoyed it, but it's not for everyone. You work for the merchant guild, but there is an adventurers guild. The adventurers in said guild can give you a chance to go into short dungeons as a chance to gain more items at a 100% profit margine. You can customize your shop a little and there's other little neat optional things to do aswell, but you can discover those yourself.My entire main story experiance took like 9 hours, I had to get the swing of things at first, but after I caught some momentum it was a breeze keeping up with every deadline amount including the last one before the deadline is a problem. I really only entered the dungeon twice, maybe 3 times. Just long enough to beat 2 bosses, which were both easy. I mostly just sold items at a great profit margine using increased priced items and did more then fine speeding right on through the game. Definatly worth the $10 I spent! (It was on sale)

er 22, 2013
												It's an interesting take on the usual RPG where, instead of adventuring, you're the shop owner.  The game is about a girl name Recette that is living all by herself ever since her father ran away.  She originally created the shop in order to shoulder the large debt that her father had built up over the years.  Tear, the other character the game gets its name from, is a debt collector that helps manage the store so that you can maximize your profits.While this seems like just a boring management game from my description, it actually does have moments where you can go out and fight monsters.  Recette can hire heroes to help her collect items to sell in her store.  The game turns into an action RPG for those moments with gameplay that's not dissimilar to the top-down entries in the Legend of Zelda franchise.This game has colorful characters that populate the city.  While most of them are kind of cliche, it fits with the game's atmosphere.  This is supposed to be an action RPG from the eyes of Recette, the girl who runs the item store.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2014
												I daresay that Recettear is one of my all-time favorite games. Having played well over fifty hours of the game at this point, I feel the need to update my review (which was already positive).In Recettear, you play as a young girl named Recette, whose father went missing while out adventuring and left behind a mountain of debt. When a faerie named Tear comes to collect on that debt, she suggests that Recette convert part of her home into a shop in order to come up with the money or risk losing the house outright. That's where the game begins.There's so much more to Recettear than buying low, selling high and scouring dungeons for loot to sell at 100% profit. The game *does* revolve around buying/selling and dungeon-crawling, but these two different aspects of the game complement one another in several meaningful ways.Dungeon-crawling will definitely net you plenty of items, but they're usually not very valuable. However, you can find ingredients that you can, in turn, fuse together at the guild to create more valuable items. Also, you'll meet new adventurers in dungeons, and they'll eventually become regular customers at your shop.Buying from and selling to the aforementioned adventurers in your shop allows you to build relationships with them while also allowing them to gradually spend more money at your shop. They'll purchase equipment from you for use in dungeons, as well, freeing up space in their inventories that you'd probably otherwise use when lending them equipment.There's more to managing your store than just buying and selling items, though. You can change the carpets, counters, flooring and walls of your store to attract different customers. You can expand the size of your store to allow you to stock more items. You can put different items in your display windows to attract different customers. You can take advantage of local fads in order to sell certain types of items in large numbers while also attracting more customers.Even more interesting, in addition to buying and selling based on regular market fluctuations, you'll find that you can influence pricing to some extent by outright "crashing" the value of some items by selling too many of them. While this may initially sound like a bad thing, you'll have a while to purchase said item(s) at ridiculously low costs while waiting for the demand on them to bounce back. Really nice touch.While Recettear has enough to offer in terms of depth to warrant a purchase, I daresay that the game's charm is what makes it something really special. Recette's kindness and naivety makes her a really fun character, and Tear acts as an excellent foil to her in terms of personality. The various adventurers and townspeople interact with Recette and Tear throughout the game, and their individual personalities do a lot to better flesh out Recette and Tear. I can't say enough about this game's charm. The entire experience is just so great.Before I close this review, I'd like to make a recommendation to new players (or existing players who have issues with certain customers, namely the little girl who breaks your damn combos): Use a guide that outright tells you which percentages to use when buying/selling. The game does make the mistake of giving you some rotten advice at the start, and following this advice will prevent customers from leveling up and having access to higher budgets.If you're concerned about a guide spoiling the game for you, then don't be. The percentages are a very small part of the game. It's still very challenging, as you'll still often find yourself having to take chances by spending 90-95% of your money when you're just a few thousand pix away from making your weekly payment goal in order to come back and blow past your goal, giving you an incredible sense of satisfaction. You still have to play the market intelligently to win.Anyway, I can't recommend this game enough. It's easily one of the best games on Steam, and I daresay that it features some of the most charming characters in video game history.

content:
14
												It's not a terrible game, but certainly has "doujin" taste to it, despite it's look and presentation.This game is a mixture of dungeoun crawler and monopoly sim together. Is this fun? It sure is. As the game was released (the first copy, not steam release) you do have to accept the fact that this game is aged. The graphic is near PS1, or early PS2 titles. Music is nice and cheerful. Story is charming, despite its actual story isn't. I think the character is helping out a lot. Recette, the protagonist, needs to pay her runnaway-father's debt of his house, otherwise she will be homeless.The sim itself is well made- you have certain amount of time in each day (works like turn basis) and you have few options to get yourself a money; buy/sell from other store, hire a client for dungeon crawling, or open your shop. Your merchant level increase by selling item in FAIR prices, and as it goes higher, you can sell things differently- such as custom order, or purchase vending machine, etc. Each customer will have different preference. So, you likely don't sell long sword to a little girl well, she would likely want to get food or books. Time also affect what kind of customer you'll bring in.The dungeoun crawling is very straight forward, but the dungeon is randomly generated. You can use an item you find in dungeon, or save it to sell them later.Unfortunately, the game has 1 massive issue for me- the sheer difficulty. Almost to the point of unnecessary. Each week you have a set of debt that you need to pay back. The debpt increases by each week, however, it increases in such a rapid pace- first week is 10,000 second week is 30,000... so on. This is caused by the fact that you only have 5 weeks to finish the payment. In order to finish game fast, you have to have pure luck, as the entire game is randomly generated. The random event occurs from 2nd week (such as gold booming or bad reputation towards all of sword) and I truly mean randomly generated- even if you save/load, you will get random event. The meeting with important character (playable) is also randomly generated. All of the treasures in dungeon is randomly generated. To cover this issue, the Recettear allows you to carryout your items once you hit "game over". Your money will reset to 1000 while all of your items remains the same. I understand that forcing you to cycle the game was their only plan to make this game feel less short then already is. THe problem? Well, once you got gameover, you will be sent back to day2. You can repeat this over and over until you beat the game. It gets repetitive, I also felt less encouraged to go back to day 2 from day 30. This game is impressive "doujin" game, as this entire project was done by single person. Still, $20 price tag can seriously compete with other titles. The game itself is good, however, it may not fit for everyone. It's worth giving a try.If I had to give a score it would be 6.5/10.Another nice note: this game is old enough to play with my crappy 8inch tablet. Nice.

content:
, 2016
Product received for free
												I recieved this game as a gift. I had been wanting it for quite some time. I was not disapointed. As a critic of many games I am pretty picky. I have to give this game 4 and a half stars out of 5. I am a fan of simulation games. However most games where you run a shop are so shallow, and empty. What I love about this game is you can go out, and find stuff while defeating monsters. It is one step up from Hometown story because of that. Sure Hometown story you can find things, but they are far, and few between. you also dont fight monsters. I enjoy how customisable the shop is. The story line is so enjoyable. This game has intertained me the whole time. Even if you fail paying off a debt, and have to start at day 2 you keep all your levels, and items on hand. I was so greatful for that. I have not come across many bugs. every now and then the game freezes for a minute. There are few things I would change. However I would like the character to be customisable, and to be able to dress her in differint clothes. maybe as she levels up she gets more options. Hometown story had that option. I understand her name being unchangable. I do not know if you will make any chages since this game is not new. However if you do make a sequal I will look forward to playing it. I will probably purchase it myself. and hopefully give it 5 stars.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2015
												In a lot of RPGs you play the hero that must save the world. But heroes are not alone; they need to find friends to fight with and shops to buy weapons, armor and healing items. This game dares to ask "what if you were the NPC standing behind the desk in the item shops?"Yes, you read that right, in Recettear you play as Recette Lemongrass, the cute loli who runs an item shop to repay her father’s gigantic debt. So if you're looking for a big adventure you might want to look somewhere else, but if you're looking for a good administration game then you've come to the right place. Even though it's labeled as an RPG, Recettear is mostly a strategy game: you must know what to buy, what to sell, at what price, when to open your shop, when to buy items and when to go to dungeons. You must do everything to make sure you can pay the required amount of your father's debt by the end of the week. As you level up, you unlock new abilities such as taking orders, fusing items, customizing and expanding your store, so you won't be doing the same all over and over.In general, Recettear offers a very plant experience and a good challenge; however it does have a few downsides. First of all, the dungeons despite being randomized will feel very repetitive after a while: in every floor you will be running in endless narrow corridors and square rooms, making the enemies and the layout (which are also repeated several times) the only variation. The postgame doesn't have much to offer either, aside from the survival and + modes all you will get is a 100 floor dungeon that continues the story but introduces no new enemies or layouts and a 30 floor dungeon where you'll be dead before you notice even if your adventurer is level 99 (but hey, at least the later offers a bit of challenge). After you clear the main quest you don't need to pay any more debts so running your shop, which is the main aspect of the game, becomes pointless.In summary: despite the dungeon system not being the best, the shop managing is really well done and anyone who enjoys administration games should try Recettear.

content:
4, 2016
												This game is absolutely amazing. I Loved every bit of it, in fact I crave more. I have only two complaints and one question. My first compliant is the difficulty. The first and second payment is fairly easy to get, but you start to get big jumps in payments and as a new player the jumps were too much for me to handle. Good news about this though is that the game wlil start you over on the second day and you get to keep all your items and level (you start over with 1,000 pix though). And while this makes you more expirenced the next time around your more likely to win after that, I much rather if they had put the increased time to extend the game. Instead of hte game taking place in just one month why not three? Let the first six payments be easy to pay so you have time to dungeon crawl and explore. I wanted to explore the world more and I wanted to get more content out of the game. Which leads me to the second complaint, it was too short. It wasn't so short that I wouldn't reccommend the game, it's just the game is so good it leaves you wanting more. After beating the game you get endless mode, which allows you to keep going through the game for as long as you want, which allows you see additionial content. You also get survival mode, which is a mode where payments keep increasing until your overwhelmed, I liked how it was introduced at the end of the game too. The one extra mode you get is new game plus, which allows you to keep all your levels and items but still get to start over. The only other thing I can think of that might turn someone away from the game is the launcher, it's more like a visual gameboy advance launcher. I don't entirely understand why that is, but it didn't bother me. Over all this game left me craving more and wishing they would have had put more content into it. But the content that is there is without a doubt good enough and enough there for me to recommend this game. It is an awesome game that I would reccommend to pretty much anyone, except someone who absolutely hates management games.

9, 2012
												I really love this game! Not only I'm a sucker for anime-graphics and little 2D pixely characters running around a 3D World, but this game is a lot of fun too! In this game you open an Item shop in a fantasy world (the kind that sells potions, weapons, armors, etc.). The characters you meet are all interesting, the story line is nice but that's not the main point, you can go in dungeons too for loot (You hire adventurers that you later control in an action-gdr manner, nothing too complicated) or simply hang out in some of the "social" places in the map to watch some cutscenes. Overall I find this game very relaxing and fun, I will 100% recommend this, but only if you're into this stuff, I understand this is not for everyone... For me it's a genius piece of art and fun, pure and simple.

content:
2016
												This game is a lot of fun!I went into this game expecting an average game due to the look on the cover, but I got something that actually surprised me in how fun it was. To give a brief summary of the gameplay, you are a shopkeeper selling villagers and adventureres items in order to pay back debts. So basically it is the other side of the gameplay in most RPG games which makes it entertaining. The game is rather easy to understand and get a hold of and is realitvely short once you understand it. Paying off the debt isn't actually that big of a challenge, but its fun to work to that. There is also an ARPG mode where you can explore dungeons and get items back to sell. Although the game is pretty fun, it starts to get repetitive near the end. However, due to the shortness of the game, unless you continue on in endless or survival, it is the perfect amount to keep you interested. Overall, fun game to play especially if you like the feeling of making profit (like me. I always go play the role of merchant in games I play and try to horde and maximize profit haha).Rating: 8.6/10Recommend: under $5

												I bought this game two weeks ago and have already put 80 hours into it (Thanks, unemployment!). The game is cute as hell and the fighting plays like a mix of Illusion of Gaia and Star Ocean. The store mechanic is actually interesting, where I find stuff and can't wait to sell it so I can get money to buy stuff which I then, in turn, can't wait to use in the dungeons. Excellent balance and great at keeping things fresh. Once the main story is over, the game becomes something of a grindfest, but if you play the Disgaea series, this will be nothing new to you.

content:
9, 2014
												Recettear really surprised me, it came out quite a while ago seemingly from nowhere and it didn't get much attention. The game has very anime stylized aesthetics that will, In my mind somewhat unfairly, turn some people off to it right away, and the graphics remind me of the latest 2D Final Fantasy games. The game breaks down to you becoming a shopkeeper unwillingly and needing to buy/find/sell/and haggle in order to pay the bills and stop the bank from taking your family's house. The game feels to me like animal crossing in a way, as you can customize your store/item layout often placing things in the window to draw the attention of the people on the street, that and the fact that you start out having to repay a massive debt. The game has a very interesting dungeon system where you can hire adventurers that you take control of to go into these dungeons and fight monsters/bosses in order to obtain rare items for your store, the dungeons play out like the original Legend of Zelda game with that kind of fighting, and a  randomized dungeon each time you enter, making it less tedious if you fail the boss fights and or fail to escape. The game plays solid and starts out quite easy but almost immediately ramps up the difficulty making you have to be more cautious with haggling and be more efficient with your time if you want to keep playing. The game is fun and has very few drawbacks other than the rather sharp learning curve after your first few payments (and the dumb little girl who always tries to haggle you down below your bottom line), but even that doesn't detract from it too much as you keep your stock when you fail so you can start over with a leg up next time. My experience with this game was rather positive and it is VERY addicting, just like the games it seems to take inspiration from. If you can get it for a good price it's definitely worth your time.

content:
14
												It's not a terrible game, but certainly has "doujin" taste to it, despite it's look and presentation.This game is a mixture of dungeoun crawler and monopoly sim together. Is this fun? It sure is. As the game was released (the first copy, not steam release) you do have to accept the fact that this game is aged. The graphic is near PS1, or early PS2 titles. Music is nice and cheerful. Story is charming, despite its actual story isn't. I think the character is helping out a lot. Recette, the protagonist, needs to pay her runnaway-father's debt of his house, otherwise she will be homeless.The sim itself is well made- you have certain amount of time in each day (works like turn basis) and you have few options to get yourself a money; buy/sell from other store, hire a client for dungeon crawling, or open your shop. Your merchant level increase by selling item in FAIR prices, and as it goes higher, you can sell things differently- such as custom order, or purchase vending machine, etc. Each customer will have different preference. So, you likely don't sell long sword to a little girl well, she would likely want to get food or books. Time also affect what kind of customer you'll bring in.The dungeoun crawling is very straight forward, but the dungeon is randomly generated. You can use an item you find in dungeon, or save it to sell them later.Unfortunately, the game has 1 massive issue for me- the sheer difficulty. Almost to the point of unnecessary. Each week you have a set of debt that you need to pay back. The debpt increases by each week, however, it increases in such a rapid pace- first week is 10,000 second week is 30,000... so on. This is caused by the fact that you only have 5 weeks to finish the payment. In order to finish game fast, you have to have pure luck, as the entire game is randomly generated. The random event occurs from 2nd week (such as gold booming or bad reputation towards all of sword) and I truly mean randomly generated- even if you save/load, you will get random event. The meeting with important character (playable) is also randomly generated. All of the treasures in dungeon is randomly generated. To cover this issue, the Recettear allows you to carryout your items once you hit "game over". Your money will reset to 1000 while all of your items remains the same. I understand that forcing you to cycle the game was their only plan to make this game feel less short then already is. THe problem? Well, once you got gameover, you will be sent back to day2. You can repeat this over and over until you beat the game. It gets repetitive, I also felt less encouraged to go back to day 2 from day 30. This game is impressive "doujin" game, as this entire project was done by single person. Still, $20 price tag can seriously compete with other titles. The game itself is good, however, it may not fit for everyone. It's worth giving a try.If I had to give a score it would be 6.5/10.Another nice note: this game is old enough to play with my crappy 8inch tablet. Nice.

content:
11, 2014
												I daresay that Recettear is one of my all-time favorite games. Having played well over fifty hours of the game at this point, I feel the need to update my review (which was already positive).In Recettear, you play as a young girl named Recette, whose father went missing while out adventuring and left behind a mountain of debt. When a faerie named Tear comes to collect on that debt, she suggests that Recette convert part of her home into a shop in order to come up with the money or risk losing the house outright. That's where the game begins.There's so much more to Recettear than buying low, selling high and scouring dungeons for loot to sell at 100% profit. The game *does* revolve around buying/selling and dungeon-crawling, but these two different aspects of the game complement one another in several meaningful ways.Dungeon-crawling will definitely net you plenty of items, but they're usually not very valuable. However, you can find ingredients that you can, in turn, fuse together at the guild to create more valuable items. Also, you'll meet new adventurers in dungeons, and they'll eventually become regular customers at your shop.Buying from and selling to the aforementioned adventurers in your shop allows you to build relationships with them while also allowing them to gradually spend more money at your shop. They'll purchase equipment from you for use in dungeons, as well, freeing up space in their inventories that you'd probably otherwise use when lending them equipment.There's more to managing your store than just buying and selling items, though. You can change the carpets, counters, flooring and walls of your store to attract different customers. You can expand the size of your store to allow you to stock more items. You can put different items in your display windows to attract different customers. You can take advantage of local fads in order to sell certain types of items in large numbers while also attracting more customers.Even more interesting, in addition to buying and selling based on regular market fluctuations, you'll find that you can influence pricing to some extent by outright "crashing" the value of some items by selling too many of them. While this may initially sound like a bad thing, you'll have a while to purchase said item(s) at ridiculously low costs while waiting for the demand on them to bounce back. Really nice touch.While Recettear has enough to offer in terms of depth to warrant a purchase, I daresay that the game's charm is what makes it something really special. Recette's kindness and naivety makes her a really fun character, and Tear acts as an excellent foil to her in terms of personality. The various adventurers and townspeople interact with Recette and Tear throughout the game, and their individual personalities do a lot to better flesh out Recette and Tear. I can't say enough about this game's charm. The entire experience is just so great.Before I close this review, I'd like to make a recommendation to new players (or existing players who have issues with certain customers, namely the little girl who breaks your damn combos): Use a guide that outright tells you which percentages to use when buying/selling. The game does make the mistake of giving you some rotten advice at the start, and following this advice will prevent customers from leveling up and having access to higher budgets.If you're concerned about a guide spoiling the game for you, then don't be. The percentages are a very small part of the game. It's still very challenging, as you'll still often find yourself having to take chances by spending 90-95% of your money when you're just a few thousand pix away from making your weekly payment goal in order to come back and blow past your goal, giving you an incredible sense of satisfaction. You still have to play the market intelligently to win.Anyway, I can't recommend this game enough. It's easily one of the best games on Steam, and I daresay that it features some of the most charming characters in video game history.

content:
r 18, 2015
												In a lot of RPGs you play the hero that must save the world. But heroes are not alone; they need to find friends to fight with and shops to buy weapons, armor and healing items. This game dares to ask "what if you were the NPC standing behind the desk in the item shops?"Yes, you read that right, in Recettear you play as Recette Lemongrass, the cute loli who runs an item shop to repay her father’s gigantic debt. So if you're looking for a big adventure you might want to look somewhere else, but if you're looking for a good administration game then you've come to the right place. Even though it's labeled as an RPG, Recettear is mostly a strategy game: you must know what to buy, what to sell, at what price, when to open your shop, when to buy items and when to go to dungeons. You must do everything to make sure you can pay the required amount of your father's debt by the end of the week. As you level up, you unlock new abilities such as taking orders, fusing items, customizing and expanding your store, so you won't be doing the same all over and over.In general, Recettear offers a very plant experience and a good challenge; however it does have a few downsides. First of all, the dungeons despite being randomized will feel very repetitive after a while: in every floor you will be running in endless narrow corridors and square rooms, making the enemies and the layout (which are also repeated several times) the only variation. The postgame doesn't have much to offer either, aside from the survival and + modes all you will get is a 100 floor dungeon that continues the story but introduces no new enemies or layouts and a 30 floor dungeon where you'll be dead before you notice even if your adventurer is level 99 (but hey, at least the later offers a bit of challenge). After you clear the main quest you don't need to pay any more debts so running your shop, which is the main aspect of the game, becomes pointless.In summary: despite the dungeon system not being the best, the shop managing is really well done and anyone who enjoys administration games should try Recettear.

content:
er 22, 2013
												It's an interesting take on the usual RPG where, instead of adventuring, you're the shop owner.  The game is about a girl name Recette that is living all by herself ever since her father ran away.  She originally created the shop in order to shoulder the large debt that her father had built up over the years.  Tear, the other character the game gets its name from, is a debt collector that helps manage the store so that you can maximize your profits.While this seems like just a boring management game from my description, it actually does have moments where you can go out and fight monsters.  Recette can hire heroes to help her collect items to sell in her store.  The game turns into an action RPG for those moments with gameplay that's not dissimilar to the top-down entries in the Legend of Zelda franchise.This game has colorful characters that populate the city.  While most of them are kind of cliche, it fits with the game's atmosphere.  This is supposed to be an action RPG from the eyes of Recette, the girl who runs the item store.

content:
y 13, 2016
												This game was an incredibly pleasant surprise.  I picked it up on sale not expecting much at all and very quickly became addicted.Don't let this game fool you.  On the surface you are a sweet little girl caught in the throws of flash poverty after your deadbeat dad runs off with everything that will put food on the table, may or may not get eaten by a dragon, proceeding to leave you to pay off his enormous debts via an item shop.  In reality, this game is a corruption simulator in which you experience first hand how a little girl can become drunk with capitalism, exploit other small children for their goods then turn around to sell those same goods to the elderly at obsurd prices.  It COULD stop there but it doesnt.  Why be "we can retire early" rich when you can be "I own a back yard pool full of slaves that don't like me." rich, stop by the local adventurers guild to risk other peoples lives for your gain by sending them into a 1000 floor living dungeon that rearranges as they manage to survive.  Game's cute tho.basic Pros and Cons:Cons: -Really long winded intro with mildly redundant dialogue.  It's skippable but you almost need to suffer through the useless bits because there are not so useless bits that make sure you know what you are doing.-Some what repetative vocal sound effects that are really charming at first but get old.-Almost impossible to do your first run through without getting game overed, even as a veteran player.  The Game over is fake however, causing you to start the game over. You get to keep any items you had though.  This can be abused quite heavily.Pros:-A rediculous amount of content with well thought out features.  Every 20 minutes or so a new feature was revealed and completely delighted me.-Extremely charming graphics including environments, character art, items and dungeons.-Shop sim plus dungeon crawler combined, with tons of gear to find and hoard and tons of unlockable characters with 100's of randomly generated dungeon levels with reasonably easy but creative boss monsters every 5 floors.You will HATE this game if you are a hardcore gamer who is a diablo/call of duty, intense games only kind of person.You will HATE this game if you hate anime art styles and light hearted cheery dialogue that makes you want to vomit sunshine.You will LOVE this game if you are weeaboo as a hello kitty doll on the dashboard of a honda civic at a cosplay convention.You will LOVE this game if you enjoy hoarding loot then selling said loot to strangers at obsurd prices to feul a vicious cycle of dungeon crawling rinse and repeat.You will LOVE this game if you want the addictive side of facebook games without the paywalls.Seriously I put 18 hours into this game in 4 days.nuff said.

												I wasn't sure about this game when I bought it. I figured there was a good chance it would end up on my "wasted money Steam purchases" basket. Only a few days later, when I bothered to check it out, this game became one hell of a pleasant surprise.Recettear is a weird mix of simulation, hack & slash and role-playing, with the cute japanese kind of graphics and animations that I really love. You play Recette, the cute and naive item-shop seller girl, who's teamed up with Tear, the fairy, who at first seems like the tough business...fairy(?) personality, but already a few hours into the game, I'm getting the feeling she has a totally different agenda than the one she's letting out.As Recette, you need to manage your items shop and make money, so you can pay a debt to Tear's agency (whatever it is), so they wouldn't take your house. In addition to buying and selling routine, you can also hire adventurers and go to dungeons. In return for your payment to the adventurer, you get to keep the items you find in the dungeon, and sell them with nearly 100% profit. All in all, this game is a lot of fun, definitely worth its price, in my humble opinion.

												Recettear on the surface appears to be a a boring shop-owning simulator. and at its core, thats what it is. You run a store, but it goes so much furthur than that. Recettear ends up becoming this charming adventure that you wouldn't have expected. Running your store, questing for items, pricing, its an expirience no other game can give. Plus, it reeks of Japan, with japanese voice acting,  creatures that I couldn't explain if I tried, and flying fish, this game manages to create one of the most random and humorous atmospheres at the same time. Overall, I would reccomend this game to, anyone really. It really is an ace of all trades. Its unexpectedly charming, and well worth the buy.CAPITALISM HO!

content:
er 1, 2013
												I picked this up in a bundle on steam a couple of years ago. While this game wasn't the reason I purchased the bundle, I ended up spending more time on it than I did any other game in it. The game has a wonderfully cheeky sense of humor as you are thrust into a viciously capitalistic society. Be careful, this game gets pretty hard pretty quickly, but after losing there is a sort of "new game plus" where you get to retain all of the stuff you had previously, which makes it easier. It's easy enough to beat on your second loop through the game, but trying to beat it without ever getting a game over is much more of a challenge.There's also a whole top-down action-adventure game embedded within the capitalism simulator, which is pretty fun. It's not as good as other games of its type, but for a part of an otherwise solid game, it does its job well.

content:
ry 4, 2014
STORY & GAMEPLAYDue to her father's debt, Recette open an item store to pay the debt. A large amount of debt -_-. She runs the store with help/guidance from her fairy debt-collector 'companion', Tear. Every some period of time (about weekly) Recette must pay certain amount of money (called 'pix' in this game) to Tear. If she unable to pay, Tear will take her house as payment for the debt. Funny story, a fairy debt-collector 'companion' assist errr, more precisely, force a little girl to pay her father's debt..... ._.Although the story sounds funny, the gameplay is a little bit... hard. If you unable to collect certain amount of pix at the payment date (which getting bigger & bigger amount of pix at the next week), you'll lose your house and live in a cardbox. But..., don't worry about that... ;)Well, even with that cruel debt, the game itself is interesting to play. There are three ways to get item stock to sell on your store:1. Buy items from market & guild2. Explore dungeons to get some items there3. Fusion (combine various items to get new items)To explore dungeons, you can't go there alone. You must hire an adventurer. As more days passed & events happen, more adventurers will be unlocked. You can equip the adventurer with items you have in your inventory. If you succeed defeating monsters & bosses on the dungeons, you can bring all items you've collected. But if you failed, you can bring only few items. The dungeon is randomized so it'll never be the same when you go there again. Nice feature.You can do fusion at the guild. The variety & rank of items you can fusion is depend on your merchant level. The higher your level the more items, of course. The merchant level also affects what kind of items you can find on market & guild, and items dropped from the monsters on dungeons. Also, how much you can decorate your item store is depend on it too. It's also affect your haggle/bargain skill when you open your store and start selling items to your customers :)Capitalism, ho!GRAPHICSWell, obviously, Japanese style anime characters. I won't say much about graphics. It's good enough. Good variety of background, so much variety of items, colorful. Nice graphics.MUSICThe soundtracks is good enough. The character voice is in Japanese. But don't worry, all the text is in English :)Suggestion: If you found some problem with (menu) scrolling, see the solution here.Story: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Graphics: 8/10Music: 7.5/10Overall score: 7.8/10

content:
9, 2012
												Sure, the game starts off as your typical Japanese cutesy thing. But soon enough, you realise things. For one, customers are not your friends. You won't win any prizes for selling at cost price. You go higher... a hundred and five... hundred and ten... hundred and fifteen... High, but not high enough to make them suspicious.You'll learn how they act, what they'll spend, and go in for the kill.Adventurers will be your tools. Cavediving may seem like an extra, but it's the only way of finding some of the most profitable treasures. You don't wanna buy from a wholesale seller or such - after all, that means less profit. You'll give them some equipment, maybe some food, and then hope they come back alive. Perhaps they will. After all, you play them. But if they die, you can only take a few things with you back up. Maybe you'll sell something to them, later, when they come browsing. At just under 150% of it's base price.Underneath that cute exterior is a game about making money.

content:
er 24, 2013
												Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is cute and fun game. For me, this game is perfect collection of genres, combining a shop sim, a dungeon crawling action RPG, and visual novel style segments all into one game.The basics of the plot is that you are Recette, a young girl who's adventurer father disappears and leave behind a crippling debt that threatens to take away your home and everything in it. So you along with Tear, the fairy loan officer responsible for you paying the debt back, open an item shop. From there on out you can go out into town to buy stock and meet people, or hire an adventurer to bring items you can sell back from dungeons.The difficulty curve can be intense, with your payments going up exponentially. However, I would consider this to be a medium difficulty game. Neither the shop segments or the dungeons are too difficult, though they still can be hard and tricky.There are 8 adventurers that you can unlock over the course of the game for the dungeon portions and each has a unique combat style and abilities from one another, so there is plenty of variety whether you want to change things up or find a style that suits you best. There are also 6 dungeons, each one harder that the first but providing better drops progressively.The plot is presented in very cute visual novel style segments and is quite light and relaxed despite the goal to pay off an ever increasing debt. I find it fits the medium difficulty game play segments very well. To trigger most of the story segments requires you to leave the shop and waste a chunk of your time, but the characters are all unique, fun and quirky. It's also the only way to unlock some of your potential adventures, so it can be worth your time.All in all, I love this game. It's not to difficult to pick up and has a lot of content available so you can keep playing for hours.
