content:
30, 2015
												Have you wondered what it would be like to run a shop as an anime girl in a Japanese RPG? If so, then Recettear: An Item Shop’s Tale is what you’ve so desired. And it IS an indie game, which again shows that, as usual, the AAA games industry can’t be counted on to touch the part of us which wants to play as a pretty little girl.One of this game’s taglines is “Capitalism, ho!” Recette, the protagonist and girl, says it with a big smile, and her eyes closed. Or maybe that’s how I remember her. With her open, maroon vest, green tie, belt buckle, and those two, large, red beads, maintaining strands of her caramel-colored hair in a tail beside her head. Plus that mortified facial expression of hers, whenever she hears opinions disparaging her business. She is so young.The game, though. There’s more to it than those tan sleeves, over arms which she keeps parallel to her sides, with her palms wide open, giving the appearance of an angel. There is, indeed, more to the game. For example: does she live alone? Sort of. She lives with a fairy. Her mother seems to have passed away. And as for her dad, he seems to have abandoned her, and with lots of debt. You must be the godlike father she evidently never had. You must take possession of her body and ensure she pays off her dad’s debt so as to avoid being dispossessed of everything except, perhaps, her clothes.Alas, that form of losing leads to one of the game’s weak points. For if you do lose (if you can’t pay your in-game debtors), you start from the “beginning,” with many of the advantages you’ve accrued in your defunct playthrough. This has you suffer what was already an uninspired dungeon crawler even more, as you’re sort of playing it all over again. It is by this and other means that you get to see little Recette running around, pit pat pit pat. By these you get to see her buy valuable items at low prices and sell them at high prices. You get to watch her go to sleep and awake, and reveal her innermost thoughts to her fairy friend. And it is all well-written, well-drawn, and….

er 18, 2014
												This game startled me. It just didn't seem like it'd be that much fun... I thought it'd be maybe kind of relaxing to run a shop, and that'd be the end of it.I was sorely mistaken.This game is just plain, downright fun. Frankly, I'm not entirely sure what's so enjoyable about it. The leveling system, the shop system, the integration of dungeon crawling and the item shop, the ability to switch back and forth according to one's mood - it just allows for a very relaxing experience, with just the right amount of emotional pressure, to make you want to really do your best.I've had this game for a couple of years now, and I keep coming back to it, every now and again. It's just... well, fun.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Recettear is quite possibly my favorite game on Steam.Concept: Your father ran away and left you in massive debt.  The collection agency sends out a fairy to get someone to pay up and that just happens to be you.  What are you going to do?  Open up an item shop in the middle of RPG-ville.Yeah, that's right.  Other suckers are out there killing for loot but you're chilling back in town playing the markets and raking in the dosh.  Buy your products from the guild or from the street merchants and turn right around to sell it to the townsfolk and the adventuring crowds.  Expand your store, learn the folks, and fleece them for every red cent they've ever made.Not exciting enough for you?  Want some action or maybe some rare items to sell?  Press those adventurers into servitude and hit up the dungeons for fresh wares.  Press on, gather everything, and keep it for yourself while the so-called heroes risk their lives for your profits.  Capitalism, ho!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
16, 2016
												Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale surprises and delights on a level that I didn't expect from such a small game. There are many facets to this game that are on the surface missed, but appreciated after many hours playing the game.The story is rather simple, you are left with the care of a shop and are required to pay back a debt that your father left you with, so capitalism and careful planning are your only means of digging yourself out of this debt. At first the requirements seem staggering, as each week you progress you're required to pay back more than the last, but the game is forgiving and if you miss a payment you'll restart in a better spot than when you first started your game.This game truly shines if you enjoy item management (as I do, clearly), as well as RPG elements that aren't extraordinarily deep but yet very enjoyable. The shop management experience found in this game, as well as the bartering that you're required to do to excel, is something that I had never experienced before and found it delightful.Sound for this game is so-so, and could be better but certainly doesn't detract from the overall appeal of the game. The graphics work well for what the game is looking to accomplish. Unfortunately, the supported resolutions require me to typically run the game in windowed mode (I have multiple monitors that are connected to my desktop, and it's a hassle to go full screen with Recettear). This is a minor annoyance, but certainly something that won't affect all players.Finally, the controls work well for the game, and I typically play with a connected controller. The support for the peripheral has proven to be one of the largest draws for the game, as I can kick back in my chair and play for a couple of hours with relative ease. I use a wired Xbox 360 controller, but I'm sure that other similar configurations from either the 360 or One will function just as well.Overall, I recommend Recettear for anyone looking for a new and unique experience. This game has a lot of potential, and while I have played the sequel a little, I find myself continuing to enjoy the original. Be forewarned, however, that this game is not for everyone. If you find item management in other RPGs tedious and a piece that you'd rather avoid, do not buy this game. It really won't prove to be to your liking.

y 2, 2015
												This game starts out easy - run a shop, right?  And do a little dungeon delving on the side.And then things get serious!I waited a couple years for the sale price to be "reasonable enough" to buy it, but I think it's (at least) worth the 50% they normally put it on sale for!  It reminded me quite a bit of FF7, though maybe that's just because it's an anime JRPG.EDIT: The game is kind of a grind if you want to unlock the last two dungeons.  To do that, you need to play New Game+ 6 times!  That's actually not horrible (with breaks), since each adventurer is distinctly different from the others.  But then I couldn't make it to the end of the last dungeon - I think because of gear.  Getting the rarer ingredients for Fusion is such a grind that I stopped playing.

content:
y 31, 2015
												The sort of game you didn't know you needed. Who knew running the item shop could be more interesting than being the JRPG protagonist? Well-balanced game elements, in a fairly addicting little package. Kuwai japanese voices, but that could probably be assumed from the screenshots posted in the store. Not especially difficult, if you keep your eye on the market, but lots of aftergame content and challenge modes to give it replayability. Pretty standard action-rpg outside the shop, but a polished generic RPG is what you'd expect from a game that's really trying to hijack rather than be one. Slightly oddball charicterization keeps you in the right frame of mind. A bit niche, but nails it.Capitalism, ho! (Frankly, that line is "Show me your moves!!!"-level quotable.)

content:
er 30, 2013
												Never before have I played a game that I can describe as beautiful in such an eclectic sense. The town looks absolutely stunning on the PC. The story is rich and provoking, keeping you guessing and revising your theories as you play. The final scenes will haunt you, driving you (or at least many) to the forums to absorb and discuss thoughts on the plot possibilities. The music is captivating and enthralling, with all of its drama. With extra orchestral stabs to accent details such as how you finish an enemy, the experience really feels complete and integrated. The gameplay is familiar for fans of the previous Carpe Fulgur games, with new innovations to spice things up. Zipping around the town and dealing out devastating blows is both effective and immensely satisfying. No game is perfect, as no form of entertainment/art is immune to subjectivity but this game comes so close that it deserves a 10/10 for being worth every single coin spent on it.

y 3, 2015
												This game is surprisingly fun and challenging, I really enjoyed the idea of being the shopkeeper in the game as opposed to the hero, It was a really neat perspective to take for a game in the RPG sense. There are a couple of aspects to the game, business management, where you need to set prices, run your shop, buy more inventory to sell and pay attention to the markets. On top of that there is a action rpg element to it as well, where you take control of an adventurer and the 'loot' you find can be sold in store to customers the next day.

ry 23, 2015
												Whenever I play any RPG like Skyrim, Fable, Fallout, MMOs, whatever, there is one thing I always, ALWAYS end up doing: Nitpicking my way through all the dungeons, grabbing all the most valuable items I can carry, bring them back to shops, and sell them for as much as possible. The money I earn doing this usually turn into a dragons hoard, since I never actually spend any of it back, I just try to collect all the stuff.And along comes Recettear, a kinda roguelike RPG where doing exactly this is the core gameplay, wrapped in a painfully adorable cutesy wrapping, and carrying along with it a passably interesting story on top.My inner Jew could hardly be happier, Capitalism Ho!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2016
												An interesting mix of a shopkeeping simulation in a fantasy world with the added feature of being able to hire adventurers to go down into dungeons and restock your shop with newer and better items instead of buying them.Essentially you have three parts of the game - in your shop you can move items around, or swap them with your inventory to ensure your best and most profitable items are on the shelves (you generally can't sell items not on display so choose carefully), and then wait to see who comes in the shop and see if they want anything you have on offer. If they do you will get to haggle with them to try and eek out that extra profit if you think you can, conversely they will try and haggle down the price.In town you can meet all sorts of people - other merchants you can buy items from (haggling again, but in the opposite direction), the guild where you can craft items or also buy more stock, or the tavern and elsewhere where you can meet adventurers sometimes.Finally there is the action RPG dungeon crawler where you can persuade adventurers you have met to risk their lives getting you more stock for your shop, this is probably the weakest part of the game as the controls aren't great, the monster variation is quite small, although there are a few reasonably well done boss fights to open up new dungeons.Overall a great game and well worth playing, just don't expect too much from the dungeon crawling side of things, that is more of a chore than anything else. The story is fun and endearing, and it is interesting to be on the other side of things in an RPG for once.

content:
3, 2012
												2 parts business simulator, 1 part dungeon crawler - if that idea appeals to you I cannot recommend this game hard enough. You take on the role of the Item Shop owner in an RPG based world and supply the adventurers and regular townies with much needed supplies of every nature.But it's not just about stocking your shop - because of course no one's going to pay sticker price for your ♥♥♥♥; damn adventurers and their haggling. Warning: You may want to drown the Little Girl for never having any money ever.The smart store owner stock piles items when they're cheap and sells them when they go up in value, and if there are ingredients you just can't buy from your suppliers, well then it's time to hire a sell-sword (whom you equip and level up yourself) and kill some monsters in a nearby dungeon, complete with multiple randomized levels and some fun bossfights.Adorable art style, great gameplay, so simple and yet so much fun, easy to sink a ton of hours into. Happy gaming.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 89% YES / 11% NOGOODIncredibly interesting spin of gameplay. You constantly buy/sell items out of your item shop, then fund adventurers to go dungeon diving for you (all of which you control). I haven't played a game so intriguing for quite some time.The characters are very likeable and varied enough to adadpt to many styles of combat for dungeon exploration.The selling/buying mechanic is deep and as rewarding as you are daring. It feels great to get a high sell combo.The dialogue is fun without being jarring, which is hard for a lot of translated games. They knocked it out of the park with this one.NEUTRALI'm not incredibly fond of losing almost everything if I die, which is easy if you're playing low defense heroes, but you get use to the hitboxes of monsters so fast this shouldn't be too much of an issue the first time around.It's understated how hard you need to work for sell chains or dungeon dive as far as possible your first time around. There's a good chance your first playthrough for the first month will result in a box ending.SUMMARYThis was the biggest surprise of the year for me back when I played it. An unusually fun game, interesting concept, great dialogue, tight gameplay, and an absolute mass of content for the price. I highly recommend this title for people wanting to see what owning an item shop and haggling gameplay feels like.

content:
, 2011
												"CAPITALISM, HO!"  Are you a bad enough dude to pay off your dad's loan?Yes, it's a game about working retail.  No, that doesn't mean it isn't fun.  Haggling with customers is surprisingly intense, since you have to balance the need to squeeze as much profit from them as possible to afford the next loan payment against the risk of them breaking your combo (robbing you of experience points for store improvements) by walking away from an insulting high offer.You can also go Zelda-style dungeon crawling as the adventurers whom you're selling all the equipment to, but that's a dangerously low-profit waste of time during the story mode.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2013
												For the first 15 minutes, Recettear is a slog with it's sacchrine sweet animu story, music and characters.  The talking (and by talking, I mean reading) carries on forever as the stern midrif bearing librarian looking fairy lectures you on the ins and outs of being a child laborer/shop owner.  Then you finally get done with the lectures, you open your shop, you maybe go explore a dungeon for some items, and the next thing you now an hour has passed. It's a steep price entry, all that slow reading to kick things off, but once you get to the meat of Recettear, it's kind of charming.  The dungeon exploring (which you technically odn't even have to do) is not too shabby, set in real time instead of your typical turn based combat that japanese RPGs' tend to use.  Once you load up on items, you had back to your shop, put them up for sale, make a little money.  The haggling system seems kind of pointless, but you know...whateveer.  It's still enjoyable.  Not something I'd power through in marathon sessions, but if you can get past the tooth ache that the oh-so-cute setup gives you, it's an allright game.

content:
y 10, 2015
												Recettear has a great amount of gameplay for its worth. Story is fairly unbelievable. A little girls father who has disappeared leaves his daughter with a huge crippling debt. She's only 10 (I am guessing?) how is she suppose to repay his debt? Why the fairy Tear tells her to make a store so she can pay it back. The lil loli Recette gets help and turns her house into a store. While the story was fairly unbelievable and lacking there isn't much to do but if you do the RPG dungeon part more stories unfold and builds up more character for Recette and Tear and the Adventurers. Characters in the game have a huge impact. Everyone is unique and different and the events that happen make them rememberable enough. The more you unlock the more events that will happen interacting with all the characters all together. It gives incentive to do the dungeon part of the game to unlock more of these characters with their corky bits and pieces. There are two different types of gameplay here. Running the Store and the Dungeon Crawling. Running your store was great but a challenge. Everyone has a different budget and you have to learn that by personality and age. The little girl is well in fact a little girl so she doesn't have much money. Louie is poor but the more adventuring you do with him the more money he gets and if you sell to him cheap he starts to get a bigger and better budget. It's so crazy and complex that each character in the game has specific things and goals and all this other crap that it's difficult to explain! Combat was simplistic but each Adventurer has their pros and cons and a different playstyle required. Not much to talk about here but it kinda reminded me of Final Fantasy without the turn base thing. Long story short, scamming off little girls or spent your life living in a cardboard box. Whats your choice?
